article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: The expression "riding shotgun" is derived from "shotgun messenger", a colloquial term for "express messenger", in the days ofstagecoachtravel the person in the position next to the driver. However, apparently the phrase "riding shotgun" was not coined until 1919.cite webMartinGaryRiding shotgunhttp://www.phrases.org.uk/meanings/riding-shotgun.html19 April 2013It was later used in print and especially film depiction of stagecoaches and wagons in theOld Westin danger of being robbed or attacked bybandits. A special armed employee of the express service using the stage for transportation of bullion or cash would sit beside the driver, carrying a shortshotgun(or alternatively arifle),citation neededJuly 2012to provide an armed response in case of threat to the cargo, which was usually a strongbox. Absence of an armed person in that position often signaled that the stage was not carrying a strongbox, but only passengers.cite webhttp://www.phrases.org.uk/meanings/riding-shotgun.htmlRiding shotgunphrases.org.uk1 May 2010
article.heading: Modern usage
article.paragraph: More recently, the term has been applied to agame, typically played by groups of friends to determine who rides beside the driver in a car. Typically, this involves claiming the right to ride shotgun by being the first person to call out "shotgun". While there exist myriad additional rules for the game, such as a requirement that the vehicle be in sight, nearly all players agree that the game may only begin on the way to the car.cite webhttp://www.bored.com/shotgunguide/index.htmShotgun Rulesbored.com1 May 2010cite bookTom DalzellThe Routledge Dictionary of Modern American Slang and Unconventional Englishhttp://books.google.com/books?id25 July 2008Routledge1-134-19478-1877In addition, a number of humorous rules for calling shotgun has been developed by organizations and individuals (for example, the "survival of the fittest rule").Rules of shotgun, Shotgunrules.com, Retrieved 27 March 2015.The Shotgun Rules, version 1.1by the Airborne Early Warning Association, Retrieved 27 March 2015.Rules of shotgun: The 25 Universal Rules of Order for Riding ShotgunBy David A.
